title: Friday, 5th May, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM11:01am

Ya!

PM11:01am

Welcome to Markets Live

PM11:01am

Yes, we are alive

11:01 am
PM11:01am

Sorry about yesterday

PM11:01am

Issues fixed

PM11:02am

Let's press on

11:01 am
PM11:02am

Cos, for a Friday, quite a bit going on

PM11:02am

Between oil price slump, re-re-re-re-restructurings at places like Pearson, French elections..

PM11:03am

But there are also some noteworthy board moves

11:03 am
PM11:03am

Not least Archie Norman becoming chairman of Marks & Spencer

PM11:03am

Now, that's been good cause to go back through Archie's glittering career

PM11:04am

But of the takes I've read this morning, everyone seems to ignore the one true shinning moment

11:03 am
PM11:04am

So we will use that as our pic of the day.

PM11:04am

I consider this priceless, in pic terms

PM11:04am

11:04 am
PM11:04am

Archie is second from the right, of course

PM11:05am

The Knutsford Four

PM11:05am

Floated in the autumn of 1999 -- reverse takeover

11:05 am
PM11:05am

£5m cash shell became valued at £70 or £80m almost immediately

PM11:06am

For no reason that the guys on board

PM11:06am

Archie

11:05 am
PM11:06am

NIgel Wray

PM11:06am

Nick Leslau

PM11:06am

Julian Richer

11:06 am
PM11:06am

It was said at the time that they might place to take M&S over!

PM11:07am

Didn't happen of course

PM11:07am

Here's the original reverse doc

11:07 am
PM11:07am

http://www.investe...9911020701260919A/

PM11:07am

Ended up as this http://www.dailyma...om-in-the-red.html

PM11:08am

Crazy days

11:07 am
PM11:08am

Statements like this along the way

PM11:08am

http://www.investe...0002011618048152E/

PM11:08am

But that's enough history

11:08 am
undefined
PM11:08am

But this is genuinely interesting news for M&S

PM11:09am

Norman was a brilliant retailer / grocer

11:09 am
Marks and Spencer Group PLC (MKS:LSE): Last: 377.42, up 19.92 (+5.57%), High: 378.60, Low: 359.60, Volume: 6.87m
PM11:09am

Hence the price move

PM11:09am

Swannel, while a brilliant corporate financier, probably had less ideas, operationally

11:09 am
BE11:09am

...................... Hm.

PM11:10am

(Forester -- nah. Proper photo shoot.)

BE11:10am

Yes, okay, if you're wanting a name to pin on a retail turnaround then Norman's as good as there is available.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

But, it's M&S.

BE11:10am

We've been here before.

BE11:11am

I mean .....

11:10 am
BE11:11am

https://www.ft.com...-a1b4-00144feab49a

PM11:11am

Well yes, this is true

BE11:11am

.... "improve the efficiency of capital spending, drive geographic expansion, and capture some of the ground lost to rivals in internet and homeware retailing."

11:11 am
PM11:12am

That was seven years ago. Shush!

BE11:12am

We can just cut and paste that, right? We can just cut and paste that every seven years, in truth.

BE11:12am

Actually, before I go on, here's Shore.

11:12 am
BE11:13am

Mr. Norman is a formidable appointment who, alongside Steve Rowe, who is CEO of M&S, means that there are two very strong characters at the helm of a once great British label that is trying to refind its purpose and relevance to the British shopper to profitable effect.

BE11:13am

This is Clive Black, of course.

BE11:13am

Few in the City and the retail channel do not know Mr. Norman, who had a sojourn in British politics as the man from Tunbridge Wells, alongside his distinguished commercial career. That career has seen him hold a senior role at Kingfisher but most notably alongside Allan Leighton, lead one of the greatest turnarounds in British commercial history at Asda before it was sold to Wal-Mart. In addition to his Asda days though he also has gained insight and experience as a Chairman and adviser at Energis, Hobbycraft, ITV and Lazards.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

We wish Mr. Norman well and hope that he can contribute to what appears to be a turnaround that has now commenced under Mr. Rowe's leadership. Indeed, the M&S CEO has demonstrably led from the front, currently driving the clothing and home activities of the group, responsibilities that should ease from the autumn with the recent announcement of Jill McDonald as the group's new Managing Director for Clothing, Home & Beauty (CH&B).

BE11:14am

With more time to consider strategic matters in due course, assuming the stabilisation of the CH&B categories, the combination of Messrs. Norman and Rowe should be a force for good for M&S in our view. Accordingly, in conclusion, we welcome this appointment, which further underscores our positive watchlist position on M&S' shares ahead of the group's FY2017 preliminary results that are set to be issued on the 24th May 2017

PM11:14am

See what I mean? No one mentions Knutsford

11:14 am
BE11:14am

You're not wrong.

BE11:15am

The point, though, is that M&S has been in turnaround for as long as any of us can remember.

PM11:15am

My entire adult life

11:16 am
BE11:16am

It's tried every approach available. The charmer, the continental guy with the offbeat ideas, the pragmatic guy who did okay in the lower leagues ....

BE11:16am

(.... yes, the parallels with football management are unavoidable.)

BE11:17am

But the problems of M&S remain the same: it has too much floorspace, owned not leased, and the customers who tread that floorspace are dying quite rapidly.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

It has a good food business but previous aggressive expansions of that have been a bust.

BE11:18am

And previous management, going back a very long time, have scrimped and saved on basic stuff like stock management and store refits.

BE11:18am

Which means Bolland, for example, could chuck £1bn at these things and make no tenable difference whatsoever.

11:18 am
BE11:19am

Perhaps Archie will do better, because he's Archie.

BE11:19am

But is that an investment case? Not really. It's a cult of personality.

PM11:19am

Blimey Bryce, you sure know how to throw a damp cloth on things Omg smile

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Yep.

undefined
BE11:20am

Did we do a price, actually?

11:19 am
Marks and Spencer Group PLC (MKS:LSE): Last: 376.40, up 18.9 (+5.29%), High: 378.60, Low: 359.60, Volume: 7.38m
BE11:20am

We have now.

BE11:20am

Right! What else? Pearson?

11:20 am
PM11:20am

It's lower live you'll be glad to hear

PM11:20am

Yeah, ok Pearson

PM11:20am

Where the price hike is truly unfathomable

11:20 am
BE11:20am

Well, good. And this surely isn't another damp cloth moment. These are tremendous results from a CEO in full control of the situation!

Pearson (PSON:LSE): Last: 745.50, up 87.5 (+13.30%), High: 773.00, Low: 726.00, Volume: 6.64m
BE11:21am

what we have is more cost cuts.

11:21 am
PM11:21am

http://www.investe...1705050700082634E/

PM11:21am

If you are a senior manager, sitting in one of the divisions at Pearson, below the board, you really must be losing the will to live

BE11:22am

Let me just do a quick inbox search of "jam tomorrow"

11:22 am
BE11:22am

BE11:22am

Yep. Thought so.

PM11:22am

Who is that? Liberum?

11:22 am
BE11:23am

Liberum, Jefferies, Northern Trust, CS, some others I probably can't name in case they're desk notes ......

BE11:23am

Jefferies for the summary.

BE11:23am

Cost savings of £300m will cost £300m to achieve, and will impact in two years. However, it was still unclear whether all of this is as a result of rightsizing the cost base or some may be achieved through the divestitures. We remain sceptical that the digital transition will enhance value capture for PSON near term, and view the interim period of managing the decline of the physical business as challenging and therefore posing significant execution risk.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

"Eightsizing the cost base" is a great phrase. Not easy when your core business might or might not be in an unprecedented structural decline, tho.

BE11:24am

Costly savings: £300m of cost savings are planned by the end of 2019 using 2017 numbers at current FX as a base. The cost of achieving the savings will also be c.£300m, therefore the cost of achieving will be suffered before the benefit is seen. There are also concerns from analysts that the £300m of cost savings may include some of the businesses the company already plans to divest. It will take two years for the plan to be realized as it relies upon IT restructuring, HR and finance as well as rightsizing the US business. Cost savings urgency was driven by the drop in profit from US higher education, which was much faster than management thought, as rental rather than purchase of textbooks and digital rental reduced the value PSON was extracting from the market. These should continue to be a drag on the business in the next few years before Pearson starts to benefit from digital transition; as we have seen in the music industry and elsewhere, the transition to digital for a legacy business is a difficult one, and we see significant execution risk.

PM11:25am

Somehow the market gives Fallon a pass, thinking the mess that is Pearson was somehow the previous management's fault. But he was the key man in the previous management -- the reason why it became known as The Ark internally.

11:25 am
PM11:25am

As in had two of everything

PM11:01am

It's working!

PM11:26am

Go figure

11:27 am
BE11:27am

Well .... I guess he can change his mind on rightsizing the business for contraction rather than growth. What baffles me is why the strategy he's adopted continues to hinge on college students in 2020 not knowing about the internet.

BE11:27am

Baffling.

BE11:27am

US courseware: US courseware is the biggest market for Pearson. This has seen a 30% decline over the last few years driven by college enrolments. In the last year, the major drain on profitability has been from the secondary market (an increase in rental physical books and digital sales and rental). Management stated on the call that they see the digital transition in US courseware as a $25m revenue opportunity for them with 70% drop through to profit longer term (after legacy business cost has been taken out). However, this assumes execution of reduction in the legacy business is strong and that PSON takes share in rental and digital to capture the value from the transition. We view the transition as potentially more painful to the business than management, with risk of disruption.

11:27 am
BE11:28am

(@Longandwrong: I'm not sure of the point you're making. One's a one-off cost and the other's a repeating benefit?)

BE11:28am

Strategic review of K12: Revenue of K12 was less than £400m in 2016 with high-single digit margin, which is at the lower end of Pearson's group margin. Sale of K12 is a possibility but this could also be a JV or partnership; management is not committing to a sale.

No comments: Management would not comment on the Penguin Random House negotiations as they are ongoing, have not been drawn on the level of sustainability of the dividend and are keeping options open on the future shape of the business. Management would not confirm that the £300m cost savings could simply be added to the 2020 profit line.

H1 operating profit: Management stated that the profitability will improve from H116 £15m as the cost savings made last year flow through, however this is as expected.

Valuation: After the short squeeze this morning, Pearson is down 11% YTD. Pearson trades on 2018E PE of 14.7x vs. peers of 15.2x, EV/EBITDA of 9.6x vs. peers of 11.1x.

PM11:29am

(DuncanDonut -- sorry, printed as much as we can on that. if/When we get more info, i will share it.)

11:29 am
BE11:29am

And Liberum, since you mention. Ian Whittaker's sell advice on Pearson is a companion piece to his buy advice on ITV.

BE11:29am

We think investors looking for this £300m “digital dividend” to 2020E estimates will be sorely disappointed:

Past evidence suggests that extra cost savings at Pearson do not lead to more profits, it just offsets revenue declines, the £650m+ cost savings already made have been accompanied by earnings declines, not growth.
Pearson’s own words that one major source of the savings will be in North America “where we need to adjust our cost base to the reality of a smaller higher education courseware business" is an admission the problems are structural and, therefore, likely to see further pressures.
While Pearson has been at pains to claim the cost cutting has been done without impacting the business, the feedback on employee sites such as Glassdoor would tend to suggest a high degree of dissatisfaction, raising the question of how much more in savings can be done without impacting the ability of the business to compete.

BE11:29am

Management stated on the call that "We still expect for the next two to three years that the negative drag from the bad stuff is going to hurt us more than the positive benefit from the good stuff". That sounds like management are implicitly preparing the market for more downgrades in 2018E/2019E, especially as the new cost savings plans will not start to come through until 2019E. Current consensus implies FY18E earnings are essentially flat while FY19E earnings grow (we expect further declines). This "pain" would suggest those figures are too high and that even before the 2p+ earnings downgrade to adjusted EPS implied under current FX rates and the downgrades for disposals such as the US K-12 publishing business.

11:29 am
BE11:30am

Over the past five years and more, we have heard the same story from Pearson that digital will grow the business and that it will help improve margins. However, there is little evidence for that in their numbers nor much evidence as to why things should change. The US Higher Education courseware market declines have been driven by the growth of students renting physical books, suggesting an attachment to the product, whilst comments from other players such as Chegg (NR) suggest the e-textbook market has gone ex-growth due to the publishers’ pricing policies.

In fact, the story that Pearson states increasingly sounds like that of the major newspaper groups a decade or more ago. Continued cost cutting to offset revenue declines sharper and more prolonged than the market expected, with the promise of digital revenues offsetting physical declines and boosting margins but taking much longer than expected to deliver. Management’s comments on the call already seem to imply that we have to wait until at least 2020 to see the benefits of digital to come through while the evidence in the meantime suggests more pain. The simple fact is that Pearson was highly dependent on its US Higher Education business (we estimate at least 45% of group profits historically) to drive profits, a business selling textbooks often at $150-200+, and with rapid changing student buying patterns, plus pressures in other businesses, they are being overwhelmed by the challenges.

BE11:30am

Ian's been a seller of Pearson for five years!

BE11:30am

And, mostly, correct.

11:31 am
undefined
PM11:32am

Other board changes at IHB

PM11:32am

And martin Gilbert joining Glencore

11:32 am
PM11:32am

But we havent much to add on those

PM11:32am

Gilbert at Glencore will be fun for other's round the boardroom table there

PM11:32am

Some of the others

11:32 am
PM11:33am

The Intercontinental stuff is here http://www.investe...1705050701032604E/

undefined
BE11:34am

Okay, so, Intercontinental ....

11:34 am
InterContinental Hotels Group PLC (IHG:LSE): Last: 4,099, down 80 (-1.91%), High: 4,170, Low: 4,079, Volume: 191.32k
BE11:35am

Has been on an extraordinary run into today's update.

BE11:35am

Record high.

11:35 am
BE11:36am

Q1 basically confirms that Europe revpar has bounced back, and not just solely on the London sterling effect.

PM11:36am

(For those bid arb hedgies joining us as new readers regarding Paratek, I can't offer any further colour, I'm afraid. When we've got some, we'll share it.)

BE11:36am

Americas doing 2.2%, Greater China doing 3.8%, Europe 6.9% ......

11:37 am
BE11:37am

There's an easter effect in here, note, but generally it's as good as expected.

BE11:38am

The only real negative is Richard Solomons departing, though there's a straight succession plan in Keith Barr stepping up.

BE11:38am

I think I'm going to have to use the "travel and arrive" thing here, as I expect most comment on IHG will today.

11:38 am
BE11:39am

Here's Cenkos.

BE11:39am

We expect no material change to consensus estimates of $750m EBIT (Cenkos $748m) at this stage. Richard Solomons, CEO, is to retire on 30 June and will be succeeded by Keith Barr, Chief Commercial Officer. Richard has been an outstanding leader of the business, continuing the good work of his predecessor Andy Cosslett, which has evolved considerably since the Six Continents demerger. Keith's appointment should ensure a smooth succession and we expect little change initially to group strategy. The stock is expensive though trading on a 2017E P/E of 23.0x and yielding just 2.2%. We are cautious on the global economic outlook and expect RevPar to continue to soften in the US. The cash generation of the business remains eye catching but we believe better opportunities lie elsewhere, Sell.

BE11:39am

And Numis.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Our FY17 forecasts currently assume 2.1% group RevPAR growth and 3.8% system growth. We note recent guidance from Hilton (1-3% system-wide) and Choice (3-4%). Given IHG's comments on the Easter impact, we do not expect changes to consensus estimates (additionally, any upside from RevPAR increments is small as operational gearing is minimal). IHG trades on a FY18E P/E of 20.9x, EV/EBITDA of 14.0x and FCF yield of 4.5%. IHG's US peers trade on an EV/EBITDA range of 12.8x to 13.9x. In the immediate term we believe the share price outlook is largely a function of FX movements and macro outlook for the US. Nonetheless, we believe that IHG's attractive combination of high ROCE, high cash generation remains intact.

BE11:41am

And Morgan Stanley.

BE11:41am

The main surprise is the CEO’s decision to retire, but after 25 years at the company, and CEO-designate Keith Barr the obvious successor (with 17 years at IHG), we don’t see this as particularly material. After their strong recent run IHG shares now trade at 21.5x 2018 P/E and 13.4x EV/EBITDA, slightly above its US peers despite the company generating generally weaker RevPAR and system growth.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

So there we go.

undefined
BE11:41am

Barclays leading us down.

11:41 am
Barclays PLC (BARC:LSE): Last: 207.80, down 4.05 (-1.91%), High: 209.80, Low: 207.60, Volume: 12.73m
PM11:41am

Yeah, what's behind this?

BE11:41am

Goldman.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Sellers.

BE11:42am

Martin Leitgeb's the analyst.

BE11:42am

And one could argue that people who work at Goldman have a reasonably good grasp of what is happening at Barclays ....

11:42 am
PM11:43am

Well, up to a point...

PM11:43am

I went to a thing with Goldman's new cfo last night, Marty Chavez. He's very smooth.

PM11:44am

But go on

11:44 am
BE11:44am

Thesis here is that growth costs.

BE11:44am

And Barclays' buffers might, when viewed at some angles, not be fat enough.

BE11:45am

Since the beginning of the year, the capital gap between Barclays and its UK and European IB peers has widened meaningfully. The key question is whether Barclays will need to continue to build capital to narrow this gap, while its peer group focusses on capturing revenue growth.

In this note, we analyse Barclays’ capital position across three key dimensions (peer group, stress testing and ring-fencing). Important uncertainties remain around the group’s capital progression (litigation, Africa proceeds, funding of actuarial pension deficit) and requirements (CCAR for US IHC, investment grade credit-rating for its non-ring-fenced bank).

These uncertainties are the key drivers behind the wide range of capital divergence scenarios for the group (when compared to the hurdles applied by our analysis): on a pro-forma basis, our analysis suggests a range of nil to c.£8 bn

11:45 am
BE11:45am

We believe that Barclays is likely to narrow the capital divergence to peers over time. It has multiple levers to do so such as retained earnings, incremental asset reduction, or maintaining the current level of dividends for longer among others.

In our view an external capital raise is low on Barclays’ list of capital build options as historically the group has focused on alternative capital measures. That said we believe alternative capital measures are not without cost, driving a more muted outlook for dividends (and possibly also profitability). Consequently we downgrade Barclays’ shares to Sell (from Neutral).

BE11:46am

So, Barclays CET1 is at the lower end of both the UK and European peer group. Ditto leverage ratio.

BE11:47am

And a £3.6bn shortfall on the BOE's soft hurdle stress test. £5.6bn if you include the 50bp management buffer.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

(RBS is the only other bank with a shortfall. £3.1bn without buffer.)

BE11:48am

Throw in a bunch of capital ringfences and a heap of litigation risk, and you can start to see Goldman's point here.

BE11:49am

12.5% CET1 vs peers on 14% doesn't really sit well with a 40% divi payout ratio.

11:49 am
undefined
BE11:50am

Inmarsat requested.

Inmarsat PLC (ISAT:LSE): Last: 775.50, down 49 (-5.94%), High: 805.00, Low: 764.00, Volume: 2.11m
11:50 am
PM11:50am

They've added their EPS up wrongly

BE11:50am

Easily done.

PM11:50am

It's better than previously stated

11:50 am
PM11:50am

But that's not why the shares are down, surely

BE11:51am

Nope, just some folk saying the shares look rather pricey given the total lack of visibility that's inherent in Inmarsat's current strategy.

PM11:52am

Think Berenberg cut it's target, but havent seen the note

11:52 am
BE11:52am

I've got that one somewhere. Barclays first though.

BE11:52am

ISAT published a solid set of results, making for a second consecutive positive print. Combined with GX contract announcements over the past six months, we see ISAT well set for a revenue recovery and to meet its 2017-18 guidance. However, our mid-term concerns remain: supply is set to increase materially whilst demand growth should be more volatile; technological obsolescence is a question mark with VHTS around the corner (V-2 launch expected in June). With the stock having recovered from its lows, the valuation now looks unappealing. We edge our PT up to GBP7.5 (+6%) leaving c. -9% downside. We downgrade ISAT to UW.

BE11:53am

We edge up our revenue and EBITDA mid-term estimates on the back of strong Q1 results and new contracts announced. Our higher estimates are reflected in our increased PT of GBP7.5 (+6% vs. GBP7.1 prior). ISAT trades on 2017E/18E P/E of c. 28x and 17x and an EV/Capital Employed of 1.7x despite a ROCE in line with the WACC. With the stock having recovered from its lows, the valuation looks unappealing vs. our coverage universe and we downgrade ISAT to UW (from EW).

11:53 am
BE11:53am

You'll remember Inmarsat's rally from lows was partly on this idea that it would fit rather nicely into Dish Networks / EchoStar.

BE11:54am

But the US land-space spectrum thing has moved rapidly beyond the scope of rational analysis.

BE11:55am

And if you take that speculation out of Inmarsat's price, it starts to look quite expensive. Here's Berenberg.

11:55 am
BE11:56am

We remain concerned about the Maritime declines and believe
the company will find it tougher to return to growth than consensus expects. Enterprise has been significantly impacted by competition and for now remains in a downward spiral. It is our view that the easy-wins (eg Boeing take-or-pay) are now in the past and tougher comparables over the coming quarters, particularly within Maritime and Government, could highlight an underlying trajectory of slower, less profitable growth. Our 2018 EBITDA forecast sits 5% below consensus. We downgrade to Sell.

BE11:56am

While the company has done a good job in lowering 2017 expectations, in our view, consensus estimates remain too high for future periods and we expect these to trend down over the coming months. Visibility remains low and on our estimates, given the lack of near-term earnings growth, the stock will still be trading on a blended P/E (includes 66% of Ligado opportunity) above 20x well into the next decade. We believe there needs to be increased visibility or a marked improvement in underlying trends to warrant such a high multiple. Our new lower DCF-based 710p price target offers 14% downside and we thus downgrade our recommendation to Sell.

BE11:57am

Spin back on the archive for more about Echostar/Dish, Softbank/Fortress, Ligado etc etc etc. Wilton Fry of RBC has been the main champion of that idea.

11:57 am
undefined
PM11:58am

Hmm -- thanks for all that

PM11:58am

We should mention Allied Minds briefly, cos they have a bit of satellite news out this morning

11:58 am
PM11:58am

http://www.investe...1705050700072449E/

BE11:58am

Rocket

PM11:59am

This BridgeSat thing has got extra funding

11:59 am
PM11:59am

Which is perhaps interesting in that Allied Minds has to get alternative sources of fresh funding now for its underlying ventures

PM11:59am

Cos Invesco is clearly not funding them going forward

PM12:00pm

And Woodford is probably too stressed now on the matter to do much more

12:00 pm
PM12:00pm

For what it's worth, some of the people round the founders reckon the new CEO at the company really doesnt mind about the ever-shrinking share price

Allied Minds PLC (ALM:LSE): Last: 145.30, down 3.1 (-2.09%), High: 147.70, Low: 144.00, Volume: 170.97k
PM12:00pm

She hasn't had her options set yet...

12:00 pm
undefined
PM12:01pm

Look at the time

PM12:01pm

I think we are done

12:01 pm
PM12:01pm

Thanks for joining us on the right

PM12:01pm

Have a good weekend

PM12:01pm

We will be back on Monday, all being well.

12:01 pm
PM12:02pm

Bye

PM11:26am

But now the stock is up 14 per cent
